details.reused_text: China Struggles With COVID, Infections After Loosening of , 'Zero-COVID' Restrictions.

China began implementing a more relaxed version of its strict ï¿½zero COVIDï¿½ policy on Thursday amid steps to restore normal life, but also trepidation over a possible broader outbreak once controls are eased.

That was part of dramatic changes aimed at gradually emerging from ï¿½zero COVIDï¿½ restrictions that have confined millions of people to their homes and sparked protests and demands for President Xi Jinping to resign.
But they are a jarring change for China, where ï¿½zero COVID,ï¿½ which aims to isolate every case, disrupted daily life and depressed economic activity but kept infection rates low.

ï¿½But Beijing is unlikely to return to the extended blanket lockdowns that crashed the economy earlier this year.ï¿½

The changes suggest the ruling party is easing off its goal of preventing virus transmission, the basis of ï¿½zero COVID,ï¿½ but officials say that strategy still is in effect.

However, they warned, ï¿½uncertainties remain high,ï¿½ including ï¿½how disruptive the exit of zero COVID could be.ï¿½

Party leaders stopped talking about the official 5.5% annual growth target after the economy shrank by 2.6% from the previous quarter in the three months ending in June.

ï¿½But Beijing is unlikely to return to the extended blanket lockdowns that crashed the economy earlier this year.ï¿½

The changes suggest the ruling party is easing off its goal of preventing virus transmission, the basis of ï¿½zero COVID,ï¿½ but officials say that strategy still is in effect.
The user, contacted through the account, declined to give a name or other details.
But they are a jarring change for China, where ï¿½zero COVID,ï¿½ which aims to isolate every case, disrupted daily life and depressed economic activity but kept infection rates low.

ï¿½But Beijing is unlikely to return to the extended blanket lockdowns that crashed the economy earlier this year.ï¿½

The changes suggest the ruling party is easing off its goal of preventing virus transmission, the basis of ï¿½zero COVID,ï¿½ but officials say that strategy still is in effect.
But it increases the risk they might spread the virus.

Hong Kong, which enforces its own anti-virus strategy, has faced a similar rise in cases as the southern Chinese city tries to revive its struggling economy by loosening controls on travel and the opening hours of restaurants and pubs.

However, they warned, ï¿½uncertainties remain high,ï¿½ including ï¿½how disruptive the exit of zero COVID could be.ï¿½

Party leaders stopped talking about the official 5.5% annual growth target after the economy shrank by 2.6% from the previous quarter in the three months ending in June.

AP news assistant Caroline Chen in Guangzhou, China, researcher Yu Bing in Beijing, and AP writers Kanis Leung in Hong Kong and Dake Kang in Beijing contributed to this report.

China began implementing a more relaxed version of its strict ï¿½zero COVIDï¿½ policy on Thursday amid steps to restore normal life, but also trepidation over a possible broader outbreak once controls are eased.

That was part of dramatic changes aimed at gradually emerging from ï¿½zero COVIDï¿½ restrictions that have confined millions of people to their homes and sparked protests and demands for President Xi Jinping to resign.
But they are a jarring change for China, where ï¿½zero COVID,ï¿½ which aims to isolate every case, disrupted daily life and depressed economic activity but kept infection rates low.

ï¿½But Beijing is unlikely to return to the extended blanket lockdowns that crashed the economy earlier this year.ï¿½

The changes suggest the ruling party is easing off its goal of preventing virus transmission, the basis of ï¿½zero COVID,ï¿½ but officials say that strategy still is in effect.

However, they warned, ï¿½uncertainties remain high,ï¿½ including ï¿½how disruptive the exit of zero COVID could be.ï¿½

Party leaders stopped talking about the official 5.5% annual growth target after the economy shrank by 2.6% from the previous quarter in the three months ending in June.

ï¿½But Beijing is unlikely to return to the extended blanket lockdowns that crashed the economy earlier this year.ï¿½

The changes suggest the ruling party is easing off its goal of preventing virus transmission, the basis of ï¿½zero COVID,ï¿½ but officials say that strategy still is in effect.
The user, contacted through the account, declined to give a name or other details.

ï¿½But Beijing is unlikely to return to the extended blanket lockdowns that crashed the economy earlier this year.ï¿½

The changes suggest the ruling party is easing off its goal of preventing virus transmission, the basis of ï¿½zero COVID,ï¿½ but officials say that strategy still is in effect.
But it increases the risk they might spread the virus.

Hong Kong, which enforces its own anti-virus strategy, has faced a similar rise in cases as the southern Chinese city tries to revive its struggling economy by loosening controls on travel and the opening hours of restaurants and pubs.

However, they warned, ï¿½uncertainties remain high,ï¿½ including ï¿½how disruptive the exit of zero COVID could be.ï¿½

Party leaders stopped talking about the official 5.5% annual growth target after the economy shrank by 2.6% from the previous quarter in the three months ending in June.

That was part of dramatic changes aimed at gradually emerging from ï¿½zero-Covidï¿½ restrictions that have confined millions of people to their homes and sparked protests and demands for President Xi Jinping to resign.

Residents line up outside the fever clinic of a hospital in Beijing (AP)
But they are a jarring change for China, where the policy of ï¿½zero-Covidï¿½, which aims to isolate every case, disrupted daily life and depressed economic activity but kept infection rates low.

ï¿½Relaxing Covid controls will lead to greater outbreaks,ï¿½ said Neil Thomas and Laura Gloudeman of Eurasia Group in a report, ï¿½but Beijing is unlikely to return to the extended blanket lockdowns that crashed the economy earlier this year.ï¿½

Elderly residents wear masks as they visit a hospital in Beijing (AP)

A surge of Covid-19 cases in schools and businesses has been reported by social media users across China after the ruling Communist Party loosened anti-virus rules in a bid to reverse a deepening economic slump.

The reports echo the experience of the United States, Europe and other economies that have struggled with outbreaks while trying to restore business activity.

That was part of dramatic changes aimed at gradually emerging from "zero-COVID" restrictions that have confined millions of people to their homes and sparked protests and demands for President Xi Jinping to resign.
But they are a jarring change for China, where "zero COVID," which aims to isolate every case, disrupted daily life and depressed economic activity but kept infection rates low.

"Relaxing Covid controls will lead to greater outbreaks," said Neil Thomas and Laura Gloudeman of Eurasia Group in a report, "but Beijing is unlikely to return to the extended blanket lockdowns that crashed the economy earlier this year."

"Relaxing Covid controls will lead to greater outbreaks," said Neil Thomas and Laura Gloudeman of Eurasia Group in a report, "but Beijing is unlikely to return to the extended blanket lockdowns that crashed the economy earlier this year."
Social media users in Beijing and other cities said coworkers or classmates were ill and some businesses closed due to lack of staff.
But they are a jarring change for China, where "zero COVID," which aims to isolate every case, disrupted daily life and depressed economic activity but kept infection rates low.

"Relaxing Covid controls will lead to greater outbreaks," said Neil Thomas and Laura Gloudeman of Eurasia Group in a report, "but Beijing is unlikely to return to the extended blanket lockdowns that crashed the economy earlier this year."
But it increases the risk they might spread the virus.

Hong Kong, which enforces its own anti-virus strategy, has faced a similar rise in cases as the southern Chinese city tries to revive its struggling economy by loosening controls on travel and the opening hours of restaurants and pubs.

That was part of dramatic changes aimed at gradually emerging from ï¿½zero COVIDï¿½ restrictions that have confined millions of people to their homes and sparked protests and demands for President Xi Jinping to resign.
But they are a jarring change for China, where ï¿½zero COVID,ï¿½ which aims to isolate every case, disrupted daily life and depressed economic activity but kept infection rates low.

ï¿½But Beijing is unlikely to return to the extended blanket lockdowns that crashed the economy earlier this year.ï¿½

The changes suggest the ruling party is easing off its goal of preventing virus transmission, the basis of ï¿½zero COVID,ï¿½ but officials say that strategy still is in effect.

However, they warned, ï¿½uncertainties remain high,ï¿½ including ï¿½how disruptive the exit of zero COVID could be.ï¿½

AP news assistant Caroline Chen in Guangzhou, China, researcher Yu Bing in Beijing, and AP writers Kanis Leung in Hong Kong and Dake Kang in Beijing contributed to this report.
The worldï¿½s most populous nation is rapidly abandoning the mass testing, lockdowns and centralized quarantine that defined the three-year old policy.

Initial indications that China was exiting zero-COVID buoyed the nationï¿½s financial markets on expectations that the release of pent-up demand would spur consumer spending and drive an economic recovery.

"Though the market is still trading on the positive expectations, we are not entirely out of the woods, as we still have to get past the panic that might come with the first wave of infections,ï¿½ said Ma Xuzhen, fund manager at Longquan Fund in Hangzhou.
Nevertheless, China has some advantages as it tries to fend off the worst-case scenario.

Yet China faces criticism that such plans have been left too late, with resources instead focused on keeping COVID-19 out ï¿½ similar to Hong Kong, which found its health care system overrun earlier in the year.

All the necessary planning has been put on the back burner.ï¿½

The depletion of fiscal coffers and rampant public discontent are driving the easing, he said, not the countryï¿½s readiness for a wave of infections.

In this period, local government policies (are) also likely to vary as the singular goal of getting cases back to zero is gone and they are faced with a slew of new tasks.ï¿½

The fact that China is releasing the mitigation measures from zero-COVID without having fully established the methods to protect them as the pathogen spreads ï¿½ namely vaccines, health care facilities and easy-to-access therapeutics ï¿½ may make some backpedaling essential.
"The road to the full reopening could still be gradual, painful and bumpy,ï¿½ said Ting Lu, chief economist for Nomura International.
"China does not appear to be well prepared for a massive wave of COVID infections, and it may have to pay for its procrastination on embracing a ï¿½living with COVIDï¿½ approach.ï¿½

The fact that China is releasing the mitigation measures from zero-COVID without having fully established the methods to protect them as the pathogen spreads ï¿½ namely vaccines, health care facilities and easy-to-access therapeutics ï¿½ may make some backpedaling essential.
China faces a daunting task after abruptly giving up on "zero-COVID," with infections set to surge and deaths predicted to top 2 million.

Unlike the whack-a-mole pattern of outbreaks that took place in the U.S. and Europe over months and years, China is likely to see a wave of infections engulf the country all at once in a population that until now has largely avoided exposure to the virus.

And while pangs of fear were common worldwide as the virus first took hold in communities, the places that fought it most ferociously face an additional hurdle because living with the virus requires a mental shift that can be hard to accept.
He is pinning his hopes on Chinese cities imposing circuit-breakers if hospitals are overwhelmed and use of the new CanSino Biologics inhaled vaccine thatï¿½s being rolled out.
"China does not appear to be well prepared for a massive wave of COVID infections, and it may have to pay for its procrastination on embracing a ï¿½living with COVIDï¿½ approach.ï¿½
Some health experts and economists say the government wonï¿½t try and rush its exit from zero-COVID, which means moving past the virus could take time.

In this period, local government policies (are) also likely to vary as the singular goal of getting cases back to zero is gone and they are faced with a slew of new tasks.ï¿½
